Award.AwardTitle: TWC: Small: Evaluating and Improving Security in Emerging Branchless Banking Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Branchless banking brings much-needed financial services to the unbanked in both the developing and developed worlds. Leveraging ubiquitous cellular networks, these services are now being deployed as smart phone apps, providing an electronic payment infrastructure where alternatives such as credit cards generally do not exist. Over 30% of the GDP in many such nations can now be attributed to branchless banking applications, many of which now perform more transactions per month than traditional payment processors including PayPal. Although widely marketed as a more secure option to cash, these applications are generally not subject to the traditional regulations applied in the financial sector, leaving doubt as to the veracity of such claims. Accordingly, very little is known about the technical security of this revolution in financial services, let alone how it will interact with the financial infrastructure of the developed world. 

This project is conducting the first in-depth security analysis of branchless banking applications and their emerging web interfaces. The project is evaluating the current state of security in such systems and developing financial applications with stronger security characteristics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant focused on emerging payment techniques used throughout the developing world that allow those without access to traditional banking or digital payments to participate in the modern economy. These applications are driven by mobile phones, in both the smartphone and feature phone categories. We discovered that vulnerabilities were substantial throughout the ecosystem, with many applications failing to provide basic cryptographic protections for their users and deploying easily bypassable authentication. Our outreach was extensive, working not only with large telecom operators, but also with small startups, NGOs, and standards bodies including the International Telecommunications Union (ITU). As a result, there have been substantial improvements to security in this space since the inception of our work. Our work is accessible in many forms, including multiple top tier conference papers (IEEE S&P, USENIX Security), multiple internation recommendations through the ITU, and countless blog posts, magazine articles, and interviews with the popular press.

This grant also allowed us to focus on many of the traditional payment systems that are used throughout the United States. Specifically, as a means to understand why more modern mobile payments have not been widely adopted here, we spent significant time developing a comprehensive understanding of the payment card industry. Our work produced multiple methods for detecting counterfeit cards, and have resulted in the granting of a patent from the USPTO. 

Finally, this work created research opportunities for no fewer than 10 graduate and undergraduate students. The two primary Ph.D. students now work as an Assistant Professor at a top state university and a Research Scientist at a top Federal research lab.
